fields.description:
■ Present Behavior

The issue resolution "Fixed" is localized as "修正済み".
The Japanese text translates as "fixed", albeit with the nuance "it has been repaired".
Repairs are suitable for the Bug issue type, but not for i.e. Task or New Feature.


■ Desired Behavior

Users have felt compelled to recommend using the localized string "完了", generically meaning "finished" or "completed".

* As this resolution status applies to issues of all types, perhaps the intention represented by the English "Fixed" is better stated as, say, "Finished" or "Completed"?


■ Steps to reproduce

0. Sign in to a plain JIRA system, and ensure the user's locale is set to Japanese.
1. View an issue whose resolution status is "Fixed" in English.
2. Observe the present behavior.


宜しくお願い致します。
fields.summary: Japanese localization: "Fixed" resolution

fields.description:
Maybe it was removed purposefully, but accesskey+E use to Edit and issue and accesskey+M used to allow you to add comments to an issue.

Neither of these work any longer.

Surely at least accesskey+E can stay as the edit operation?
fields.summary: Accesskeys for Edit and Comment operations

fields.description: it makes unable to create localized actions for v2 plugins
fields.summary: JiraWebAction uses inappropriate class loader to locate resource bundles

fields.description:
With the increased font size, I find it difficult to determine which column is the 'old' and which is the 'new' for field changes in JIRA issues.

Typically; one will see this for the first field change, where a heading is displayed above the change:
!made changes heading.png!

But if you navigate down to the bottom of a long issue without spotting the header or if you forget which column is which; it seems non-obvious which is which without reverting to first principals:

!made changes.png!

Perhaps having the heading above each change would make it easier for new (and old) users of JIRA to determine which column is which.
fields.summary: Improve old & new 'changes' column visibility for long issues

fields.description:
Two directories called 'nullcomments' and 'nullissues' are created in the Working directory when setting up JIRA for the first time.

   1. Start JIRA on blank database.
   2. Move onto the second step on the setup wizard.

There will be a 'nullcomments' and 'nullissues' directory in JIRA's working directory.

Its caused by the JiraSystemInfo.obtainDatabaseStatistics method. This method getss the comment Searcher before the Indexing system has been initialised (thus the null*). I find it strange that we allow people to use the indexing system even though it has not been initialised yet. I would expect and exception to be thrown. It also appears that people would be able to get a searcher even when indexing is disabled.
fields.summary: Two directories called 'nullcomments' and 'nullissues' are created in the Working directory when setting up JIRA for the first time.

fields.description:
If you refresh the browser page when creating a custom avatar the session gets into an invalid state and gives strange error message, 
{code}
There is not an avatar with the specified id. Perhaps it was deleted.
{code}

Steps to reproduce:
* Log in as ad admin user
* Go to Administration/Projects
* Select a project
* Select Edit Project
* Click on the project avatar
* Select custom 
* Select upload an avatar and choose a file to upload
* DO NOT PRESS Choose avatar, but refresh the browser page
* Click on the project avatar
* Select the uploaded avatar

This will cause the error.
fields.summary: Avatar picker gets into an invalid state if the browser is refreshed.

fields.description:
In order to get more real estate out of JIRA moving the actions to the right of the JIRA logo would improve usability.

A 24px gain might not sound like much, however our customer service team only have 15" screens with 1024x768 resolution with their system DPI settings increased for larger fonts, this gain would be very significant for them.
fields.summary: Move menus and "Create Issue" button (header-bottom) into the top header area for more screen real estate

fields.description:
We use JIRA as a workload management system.
With the activity stream, the data can be aggregated, as in this example:

Michelle Bramley updated 2 fields of TWWORK-123 (Draft revised document)

This is not helpful to our project. Our due date field cannot be changed once a task is in progress, and I use the activity stream to monitor this because I cannot create a filter to search for updates to the due date field.

Two solutions:
1.  Disaggregate the information being uploaded to the activity stream, or 
2.  Enable a filter on issue searching to determine updates to the due date field.

Thanks for considering this request.

Michelle Bramley
fields.summary: Enhancing the activity stream

fields.description:
I propose that issue linking get a face-lift to make it into more of a workflow. Integrate ad-hoc filter creation as a part of the workflow. 

The pop-up dialog, which is limited to already existing filters and has a hard-limit of 50 entries, is a different UI paradigm than any other feature that can be found in the rest of JIRA.

The limit of 50 entries in the pop-up dialog is the hardest part to live with, and was the catalyst to begin this train of thought.
fields.summary: Re-work issue linking to behave more like a workflow

as a team of systems administrators, we would like to get the full group memberships of our customers displayed in the User Profile page, in order to better identify them, without being added to the jira-administrators group.
In fact, our customers are colleagues of ours who do not belong to technical divisions; however, we would like to replicate their position from the corporate organisation chart to JIRA.

Thanks,
Gabriele

fields.description:
New to JIRA (but intensely developing own as well as using foreign web application for years) I discovered a confusing German translation right in the beginning of the initial setup process (step 1). When forced to choose the 'Mode' there's missing a clear short explanation for what these modus actually imply - at least not for less experienced administrators:

---
1. Public - Any user can sign up and post issues.
2. Private - Only administrators can create new users.
---

This is already slightly confusing as for less experienced Administrators the question may rise: "So, what is it actually about? Posting issues or creating users?". But, okay, most people should get it. And yes, I probably wouldn't have posted this if there isn't the confusing German translation:

---
1. Öffentlich - Alle Benutzer können sich anmelden und Vorgänge erstellen.
2. Privat - Nur Administratoren können neue Benutzer erstellen..
---

No 1. translated back to English would read like : "Any user can *log in* and create issues.". It should correctly be translated with:

1. Öffentlich - Jeder kann sich als neuer Benutzer registrieren und Vorgänge erstellen.

To give emphasis on the idea of a "public sign up" I would also prefer an alternative for the original English text like:

---
1. Public - Anyone can sign up as a new user and post issues.
2. Private - Only administrators can create new users.
---

Maybe last idea is a bit qirky... ;-) Anyway, just my 2 cents...
fields.summary: Setup: Explanation of 'Mode' confusing especially in German translation

fields.description:
I'd like to be able to update/upgrade Jira from within the application. Most application (including webapplication) have the ability to update from within the application. This would save as a lot of time because we now have to do a complete Jira installation, configure a lot of settings and add several plugins. Needles to say that this is very time consuming (thus gives a lot of downtime), and is not failure proof. Having the ability to update from within the application would fix this.

BTW I can understand that upgrading between major versions might be a problem, but upgrades, say from 4.0.1 to 4.0.2, should be possible (I think :-)).
fields.summary: Update/upgrade Jira from within the application

fields.description:
Hello,

Jira store information regarding the state of a comment (hide or show) as a cookie named jira.viewissue.cong.cookie.
The problem is that a cookie as a maximal lenght (from 4000 to 8000 depending of broswer according to this url http://manicode.blogspot.com/2009/08/real-world-cookie-length-limits.html)

So after times, you can get it full. I currently have 174 comment state stored in my cookie (4000 char). So new state can't be append to the cookie.

I see 2 way to workaround that:
1. Store 1 cookie per issue (I think in this case this allow a huge number of comment for an issue..) or comment.
2. Add a webpage to clean the information comment by comment (I my case I could remove stored information regarding most comment because I no longer need to keep there hide/show state)

Best regards,
fields.summary: Comment hide/show storage

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-20616].
  {panel}

For the last 4 months I been using JIRA a lot.  As JIRA bug master I have a "reason" to really use JIRA.  And the way it works affects the way I can work.

I think JIRA needs a new feature.  Lets call them Lists.

A JIRA List is simply a set issues that have be "placed" together into the list.  Simple as that.

h2. Why Not Filters
Filters are "views" on some data.  If the issue data has matching attributes, then it presented by the filter.  When it not longer
has matching attributes, its not.

Lists differ in that once an issue is added to the list, it stays there.  An issue's data attributes can change as much as you
like but they are still in the list.

One does have to ensure that the data stays stable with lists compared to filters.  If you have a filter looking for unresolved bugs in v3.13.3 and some one changes the version accidently, then its out of the filter.  But with a list the inclusion condition is that at one point it was added to the list.

h2. Lists Are More Personal
Lists are more personal and/or more specific than filters.  If I create a list its because I have decided what needs to go into it.

Its not data attributes but rather human reasoning that puts issues in lists.

I figure having lists in JIRA will increase its "social value" in a sense.  A group of people can be sharing a list, and making group decisions about whats in it or not.

To this end lists should be shareable (like filters and dashboards) but also have an "editable" permisson.  Hence a list can be shared with a person/group/role and optionally have a "editable" flag also with that person/group/role.

h2. Lists Are More Transient

I can imagine lists being used in an Agile teams.

For example a "weekly iteration" can be a list, created at the start of the iteration.

Time is logged against the issues in the "iteration" list.

One could imagine that lists may be able to "add" up the time logged against the issues in them.

When the iteration ends, the list can be kept or discarded.

Unfinished tasks can be put in another "iteration" list by "dragging/copying" a list (via UI checkbox selection).

Compare this to a filter scenario.

One has to have a custom field called "Iteration" or use something like Lables.

The field needs to be set the same value in
all of the issues.

The creator of the tasks/issues has to be responsible for getting the value right to include the issues in the filter.

Then when the iteration is over, the issues need to re-edited top move them to the next iteration.  A lot of management overhead for a weeks list of tasks/issues, that are transient in nature.

h2. Lists Are More Work Process Oriented

So while fitlers may tell you what things are candidates to be done, lists can be used to make a "subset" of work you planned to do.

So from the 100 bugs you could possibly do, imagine a list of the "most important", a list of the "ones needing product management review", the ones that "you thought had been addressed before", a  "watch list", a "performance list" and so on.

So you can use lists as a.... wait for it... a TODO list.

Filters arent really TODO lists.  Once they get large that are a less useful for this function.

I can imagine that issue sin the list have a DONE status or not WITHIN the list.

So JRA-1234 might be done in list X and not done in list Y.  Contrast this with filters where once a field value is changed (say resolved) its done in all filters.

h2. Simple Features Of Lists

A list is an arbitary set of issues.
Lists have names (editable at all times like filters)
Lists are shareable
Just like filters and dashboards
Need an extra flag to idicate that those who can see the list can edit the list
They would also be "favouritable"
Anywhere you see an issue key, you get a like to add it to a list
In the issue nav / issue view page / whereever
A pop up that shows favourite list
Also the ability to start a new list at any time
List would primarily be show in portlets
Issues can be created from within the list context
Much like the sub task quick create
List can be created from other lists
The user goes into copy mode and "selects" the issues to copy across
Maybe copy to existing lists or create a new list

h2. Extended Features Of Lists

(These are less clear in my mind or are much harder)
List are sortable inside themselves
A bit like the issue navigator
Maybe by a standard set of fields
Maybe via a set of customizeable fields (like the issue nav)
Lists can be part of a project
No one owns it, the project does
Its on the Browse Project page
May create issues in a project can edit the lists (maybe not)
List would have a TODO nature for each issue in the list
So an issue in a list of DONE/NOT DONE in terms of that list
People can "check" off the issues as done
Lists can be retrieved/created via REST/SOAP
JQL could be used on a list
Select from list='list name' where x y z
fields.summary: JIRA needs support for lists of issues

fields.description:
When importing from a CSV file, if the encoding of the file does not match the platform default encoding the import fails to import issues containing "invalid" characters.

Refer to [JSP-53202|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JSP-53202]

The problem causes the issue not to be imported when MySQL is the target database, but other databases import the issue, but with the incorrect character substituted for the invalid characters.  If the platform uses UTF-8 encoding then the substituted character is the universal UTF-8 substitute character \xEF\xBF\xBD.

This might typically occur when the csv file is produced on a Windows machine and encoded as ISO-8859-1 and JIRA is running on a linux platform with its default encoding set to UTF-8.

A possible solution might be to amend the UI to allow the user to optionally specify the input file's encoding, so that the input is handled correctly.
fields.summary: Importing text with angled apostrophe, issue is not imported

fields.description:
When creating a Custom Field, I can add a description which will be displayed on the screen.

After the field is created and attached to a screen, I can change or remove this description as needed, and the description will be displayed according to the changes I´ve done.

If the Custom Field is set as required; but, after this, if I change the field description, the screen keeps showing the old value.

If a user creates a custom field without description, then it can't be edited later.

I have tested this with Select List and Date Picker Custom Field types.
fields.summary: Custom field description can´t be changed on a required field

fields.description:
We recently had a crash due to the permagen being too low, even though it was set to 256.

Shut down the service and unlocked the JIRA home directory. Now, when I try to restart tomcat it won't get past the following last two entries

{noformat}
2010-03-10 21:26:54,223 main INFO     [atlassian.plugin.loaders.ScanningPluginLoader] No plugins found to be deployed
2010-03-10 21:26:54,228 main INFO     [atlassian.plugin.manager.DefaultPluginManager] Plugin system started in 0:00:13.680
{noformat}

Now if I shot down and change tomcats port from 80 to 8080, it starts up fine.

If I delete my database, I can then start on 80 with a fresh install, then the restore of the backup works fine, but if I shut down tomcat, again, it won't start.

I can provide my backup file but I would prefer to not make it public.
fields.summary: Jira fails to start after initializing modules - Prevents tomcat from starting fully.

fields.description:
It would be good if we can stop the automatic adding new value into custom field  for unmapped custom field value (especially for Select List custom field). Use case:

I've added a Select List custom field, namely *Brand* with following values:
    * Canon
    * Sony
    * Nikon 
|

And, I've the CSV file below to import:
{noformat}
IssueType, Summary,        Brand
bug,       "First issue",  Canon
bug,       "Second issue", Sony
bug,       "Third issue",  Nikon
bug,       "Fourth issue", Panasonic
{noformat}

During the import, CSV importer will create the new value (Panasonic) in *Brand* custom field. Some users might find it useful to stop the automatic value creation, if they would like to reserve the original options created for the custom field.
fields.summary: CSV Importer - stop automatic adding new value into custom field

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-20608].
  {panel}

When going to the below (when you are logged out of EAC/J):

https://extranet.atlassian.com/jira/sr/jira.issueviews:searchrequest-xml/temp/SearchRequest.xml?jqlQuery=parent+%3D+%22SUPPORT-493%22+and+resolution+%3D+Unresolved&tempMax=1000&os_username=atlassiansupport&os_password=blah

It will show an error of "An issue with key 'SUPPORT-493' does not exist for field 'parent'", when the root cause of the issue is that the os_username and os_password combo is incorrect. 

Usually this isn't much of a big deal expect when it shows up in confluence when using the jiraissues macro and leaves poor confluence support people wondering what's wrong with parent field (which exists) when the real error is the incorrect username/pass.
fields.summary: Getting  "An issue with key 'SUPPORT-493' does not exist for field 'parent'" when the username and password is incorrect.

Please see JRA-4052 for the background of this problem.

Firstly a comment was made that http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRACOM/Merging+2+JIRA+instances was a dead link.

It looked to me that it was moved to http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Merging+2+JIRA+instances .
With this in mind I made a comment with this link in it and also edited Anton's original comment.
But now there is a new comment "You cannot view this page due to inherited restrictions. :("

fields.description:
Our company uses links extensively, but when we perform a search or export an excel table from the issue navigation page, we only see the link key.

This is a serious problem for us.
I see that information does appear on the page (when I roll over with the mouse, the issue title appears).
How can I get the Issue title to appear on the screen?

This is also relevant when it comes to release notes.
fields.summary: Getting link titles to appear in issue navigatot or export to excel

Seems it does not show versions with more then one dot in the version name - 3.1.2, 3.1.3.
See screen-shots - version names & the chart with no versions.

fields.description:
If the summary of the issue contain numbers, searching for the issue using the numbers will not return any result. This only happen if Quote is used.

Here is the steps to replicate:
# Create an issue with summary : asd qwery 12.3 lorem ipsum dolor
# Filter the issue by using "lorem ipsum dolor" (with the quote). You should be able to get the result.
# Filter the issue using "12.3 lorem ipsum" (also with quote), it will not return the expected result.
# However, filtering the issue using 12.3 lorem ipsum (without the quote), it will return the expected result.

This is reproduceable in JIRA 4.0, 4.0.1
fields.summary: Filtering the issue using number as one of the parameter will not return any result if Quote is used

fields.description:
This issue was raised from: [https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JSP-53779]:

The customer requested an improvement for the following documentation:
[http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/How+to+Rename+the+%27Priority%27+Field+in+the+Issue+Navigator]

The customer requests to include the guidelines on how to locate ($JIRA_HOME/atlassian-jira/WEB-INF/lib) and extract the language jar file which has been documented at the following page:
* http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Customizing+text

fields.description:
Hello,

we need to do a report (preferably as a linear graphic) that lets us see the number of issues open based on the component (similar to the "Average Time in Status" gadget).
It would be great if this report can be based on any particular field (including custom fields).
fields.summary: Display the number of issues over a defined period of time in regards to the assigned components

fields.description:
When someone creates an issue or adds a comment where the description/text is longer than the screen allows, the sideways scrollbar appears but scrolling to the left only shows a grey area covering the actual text. The only way to view the text is by select-dragging to the right. When doing this, the scrollbar does not move along, resulting in an inability to scroll back to the original position: select-dragging to the left works, but not all the way since the comment doesn't reach past the issue details column.

this issue appears to be IE7 and IE8-related, IE6 does it right (according to a user who reported this to me, I couldn't test this myself as I have no IE6). Chrome and Firefox don't have any problems either.

screenshots attached.
fields.summary: JIRA wide comments display issues in IE7

fields.description:
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Importing+Data+From+Mantis
says that the process is identical but the code is actually pretty different. For instance, Bugzilla supports "re-import to only get new issues" but Mantis doesn't. This means that the screenshots don't match what a user sees in Mantis, as well.
fields.summary: Mantis documentation needs to list differences from Bugzilla process

fields.description:
When logging time worked, jira's time entry uses w,d,h,m as short hand for weeks, days, hours, and minutes; however, only integers can be used for data entry.

For example:

In order to enter 1 hour and 30 minutes, you must enter 1h 30m.  It would be helpful if that same amount of time could be entered as 1.5h.
fields.summary: Add ability to log time worked using decimals

fields.description:
If you commit a change to CVS with a commit message that includes the full Issue URL, the commit isn't recognized as being associated with the issue.

Steps to reproduce:

# Set up a trivial CVS project on a repository
# Add a CVS module per [the JIRA documentation|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Integrating+JIRA+with+CVS+and+ViewCVS].
# For ease of testing, configure the VCS service to refresh every 1-2 minutes
# Set up a test project that's associated with the CVS module
# Create at least one issue
# Make a commit that references the issue's key, for example "Sample change for TEST-1"
# Make a second commit that references the full issue URL for the same issue, for example "Sample change for http://localhost:8080/browse/TEST-1"
# Make a third commit that references the issue key, for example "Another sample change for TEST-1"
# Wait for the VCS service to run.
# Check the CVS log file configured in the module setup, you should see all three commit messges.
# Check the issue, you'll see the first and third commits, but not the second

It would be helpful to be able to simply copy and paste the URL of the issue you're working on into your commit message.
fields.summary: Add handling for CVS commit messages that include full issue URLs

fields.description:
If you create a user with the web interface, leading and trailing spaces are trimmed from the username as expected.  If you create your own account using the "sign up" feature trailing spaces aren't trimmed.

This can lead to confusion if (for example) users create an account by copying and pasting their email address or username from another system and mistakenly include a space.

The expected behavior should be for the trimming to work on both the user browser and the self-signup.
fields.summary: It's possible to create users with leading and trailing spaces when signing up for an account

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

# Install JIRA 4.0.1 Standalone.
# Before running JIRA, "upgrade" the bundled Activity Stream plugin by copying it from the {{.bundled-plugins}} folder into the {{installed-plugins}} folder.
# Start JIRA

Symptoms:

* Activity Stream loads but shows no activity (no error response is thrown, just no activity)
* No error messages about loading the plugin in the logs

What seems to be happening here is that there is a problem when uninstalling the bundled plugin and then installing the "new" version. After debugging the code we've observed that the PluginAccessor throws a NullPointerException when trying to access the Module from the Descriptor.

This is fixed in JIRA 4.1 with a newer version of Felix, so it only affects 4.0.x releases.

References:
* http://code.google.com/p/couldit-autoexport/issues/detail?id=24#c0
fields.summary: Cannot upgrade bundled OSGI plugins (e.g. Activity Stream plugin)

fields.description:
If you create and issue then add a comment like:

This is NOT going to render

Then try searching for it by using the following JQL:

comment ~ "This is NOT going to render"

You will not get the search results as expected. If you try putting an emphasis on the word "NOT" like this:

comment ~ "This is +NOT going to render"

JIRA throws an error stating:

Unable to parse the text 'This is +NOT going to render' for field 'comment'.

I think that is because there is a conflict with the NOT operation as outlined here:

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Advanced+Searching#AdvancedSearching-NOT
fields.summary: JIRA not able to handle the word not in JQL

Steps to replicate:
- Create a shared filter having similar JQL:
{code}
project in (PROJECT1, PROJECT2) ORDER BY created DESC
{code}

- Execute the shared filter with a user that does not have browse permissions for project *PROJECT1*

- The resulting JQL becomes:
{code}
project in (10020, PROJECT2)
{code}

- The non-viewable projects ID is replaced with numeric ID, and the sort order is missing
- The filter initially displays the results with default sorting (_Key descending_) from under the View tab (even though the JQL summary is wrong), but once switching to *Edit* no results return with the displayed error message:
\\"_A value with ID '10020' does not exist for the field 'project'._"
- The user is unable to switch back to *simple* mode to edit the shared filter
fields.summary: Shared filter queries break when users don't have browse permissions for projects in the search query

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-20566].
  {panel}

The current separator character for user lists is a comma.  This presents a problem for large user bases where display names are commonly in a "surname, firstname" format for surname sorting, typically:

Birch, Jim

Where a list is displayed ambiguity arises.  This would occur in watch lists, project role lists, etc:

Birch, Jim, Yossarian, John, Major, Major, Minderbinder, Milo 

This is currently a problem for us and (I guess) others who copy user names from Active Directory.  It will become a problem for more people When Jira loads LDAP users from large directories.

Suggested remedy: use a semicolon or a configurable character.  This may already be settable but I couldn't find it. There may already be a solution in the pipeline with ldap support but it would be a nuisance if this were missed. Thanks.
fields.summary: Separator character for user lists

fields.description:
The MultiSelectCustomFieldIndexer does 2 things:

# index but don't store a case-folded version in the field ("customfield_10017:retail")
# store a "raw" version in a new field with the _raw added to the end ("customfield_10017_raw:Retail")

The problem is that com.atlassian.jira.security.type.GroupCF looks for "customfield_10017:Retail". It doesn't know about this raw/case-folding stuff and ends up searching for something that doesn't exist.

Brenden believes this will be true for all custom fields that you base a security level on.

The result is that JQL doesn't return things that users should be able to see.

This worked in 3.13, meaning users that have upgraded to JIRA 4.0 now are getting bogus search results.

Note that this only affects custom field values that have uppercase letters in them. This means you can work around this bug by changing the custom field values to all be lowercase.
fields.summary: JQL breaks issue security levels based on custom fields

fields.description:
When JIRA is connected to Postgres 8.3+ you cannot:

* Delete an external Gadget from the gadget directory.
* Delete an option from a cascading select custom field.
* ... (I am sure there are others).

JIRA will not work with Postgres 8.3 or higher. Users will encounter errors like:
{Code}
SEVERE: Internal server error
com.atlassian.jira.exception.DataAccessException: org.ofbiz.core.entity.GenericDataSourceException: Generic Entity Exception occurred in deleteByAnd (SQL Exception while executing the following:DELETE FROM public.externalgadget WHERE ID=? (ERROR: operator does not exist: numeric = character varying
  Hint: No operator matches the given name and argument type(s). You might need to add explicit type casts.
{Code}
I found this bug in Postgres:

http://archives.postgresql.org/pgsql-bugs/2008-04/msg00003.php

It pointed me to the release notes where it looks like a an intentional design change to require explicit type casts.

http://www.postgresql.org/docs/8.3/static/release-8-3.html
fields.summary: Some operations fail with "ERROR: operator does not exist" when JIRA is connected to Postgres 8.3+

fields.description:
We find quite commonly that for some filters we need to see a specific set of columns and for a different filter we need a different set of columns to be able to effectively use the data displayed.

I imagine this could be added to JQL syntax, here is an example
"issutype = bug and assignee = assignee = currentUser()ORDER BY priority DESC, key DESC COLUMNS (T,Key,Summary,Pr,Res,)"

This would then override the users current navigator settings and show just those 5 columns.

This is similar to the 'show saved filter with columns' but having it in the issue navigator would allow people to go straight to options like bulk edit and export to excel (current fields).  Also means that the users default column selection for the issue navigator would not need to include the more obscure fields that are only used for certain activities - as mine is at the moment!
fields.summary: Allow a user to define which columns are displayed on a per filter basis (overriding the defaults)

fields.description:
If you use the windows installer to install a new version of JIRA and you already have a previous version of JIRA, the same home directory is used. 

This has a number of knock-on effects. Firstly, it wrecks the contents of the home directory for the previous version. Secondly, the new JIRA may fail to start, for example if the JIRA home directory is locked.

The installer was deliberately made to install JIRA in a version specific location and to check that system singletons like the network port are checked to see whether they are available so that the upgrade instructions (install alongside then test and cut over) would work with the installer.
fields.summary: Windows Installer does not use version specific jira home directory

fields.description:
The old local_rpcplugin_javadoc script in atlassian-scripts no longer works since the 4.0 era move of RPC to maven 2.

Now maven 2 provides a javadoc jar mechanism we should probably just use that to publish javadocs and then unpack it into the correct place on www.atlassian.com for a published set.

Also update the How To Release A Verion Of JIRA wiki page
fields.summary: Create maven 2 way for publishing RPC javadocs to wac

fields.summary: Username with whitespace in the end gets "<username> does not exist"  when trying to add user to project role.

fields.description: One thing that came up when QAing JRA-8248, is a minor pickle when you archive versions in the target project then you cant select those in the bulk move.  That's consistent with the edit screen of view issue, but I think in bulk move, you may want to select archived versions more often, because you could be merging really old projects with lots of archived versions.  There's a pretty easy workaround though: Unarchive versions first in the target project. We should probably include this as a hint in our docs for this issue.
fields.summary: Add a documentation hit for bulk move and retaining versions when versions have been archived in the target project
